conclusion: Determine the power of the external force doing work when the conductor rod OC rotates uniformly in a magnetic field.
The conductor rod OC is rotating with an angular velocity ω in a magnetic field B.
The length of the conductor rod OC is r, and the angle it makes with the horizontal is θ.
The velocity of the end C of the rod is given by v = rωsinθ.
The induced emf in the conductor rod is given by emf = Br²ωsinθ.
The resistance R is connected between O and C, and the resistance of the conductor frame and the conductor rod are negligible.
The current I in the circuit is given by I = (Br²ωsinθ)/R.
The power dissipated in the resistor is given by P_dissipated = (Br²ωsinθ)²/R.
The power of the external force doing work is equal to the power dissipated in the resistor, P_external = (Br²ωsinθ)²/R.
The angle θ is not specified, so the power of the external force doing work is in terms of θ.
Assume the average value of sinθ over one complete rotation is 2/π.
Without the specific angle θ, the most general form of the power is P_external = (Br²ωsinθ)²/R.
Considering the average case over one complete rotation, the power is (B²r⁴ω²)/R.
